metadata.title: Supplementary Information for MoleGuLaR: Molecule Generation using Reinforcement Learning with Alternating Rewards
metadata.venue: Journal of chemical information and modeling
metadata.journal: Journal of chemical information and modeling
metadata.abstract: The design of new inhibitors for novel targets is a very important problem especially in the current scenario with the world being plagued by COVID-19. Conventional approaches such as high-throughput virtual screening require extensive combing through existing data sets in the hope of finding possible matches. In this study, we propose a computational strategy for de novo generation of molecules with high binding affinities to the specified target and other desirable properties for druglike molecules using reinforcement learning. A deep generative model built using a stack-augmented recurrent neural network initially trained to generate druglike molecules is optimized using reinforcement learning to start generating molecules with desirable properties like LogP, quantitative estimate of drug likeliness, topological polar surface area, and hydration free energy along with the binding affinity. For multiobjective optimization, we have devised a novel strategy in which the property being used to calculate the reward is changed periodically. In comparison to the conventional approach of taking a weighted sum of all rewards, this strategy shows an enhanced ability to generate a significantly higher number of molecules with desirable properties.

S2 Reward Functions

The reward functions for each property are mentioned in Table S1 where x is the predicted property and t is the target value.

S4.2 Alternating Rewards


S5.3 Grid Generation and Docking

Docking methodologies are crucial in the initial stages of drug discovery for a novel target to determine molecules that have a high binding affinity to the target protein. In this study, docking calculations are used as a method for the generator to learn the characteristics of the binding pocket of the target protein so that it starts generating molecules complementary to it, i.e., molecules that have a high binding affinity.

10 Figure S8: Molecules generated by model optimized for sum of rewards from BA with TTBK1 calculated using AutoDock and target LogP = 2.5

Docking was done using AutoDock-GPU, 4 which consists of a GPU implementation of the Lamarckian Genetic Algorithm (LGA) giving an immense improvement in speed in comparison to AutoDock. The Autogrid4 utility in AutoDock was used to generate the grid maps for each atom type along as well as electron density maps and desolvation maps. The grid spacing, grid size and grid box center mentioned in Table S5 and are set to encompass the active site.  14 Figure S12: Molecules generated by model optimized for alternating rewards from BA with SARS-CoV-2 M pro calculated using AutoDock and target LogP = 2.5 Figure S14: Molecules generated by model optimized for alternating rewards from BA with TTBK1 calculated using GIN, target LogP = 2.5 and target QED = 1 Figure S15: Molecules generated by model optimized for alternating rewards from BA with TTBK1 calculated using GIN, target LogP = 6 and target QED = 1 Figure S16: Molecules generated by model optimized for alternating rewards from BA with TTBK1 calculated using GIN, target TPSA = 120Å 2 and target ∆G Hyd = -11 kcal/mol Figure S17: Molecules generated by model optimized for alternating rewards from BA with TTBK1 calculated using GIN, target TPSA = 70Å 2 and target ∆G Hyd = -11 kcal/mol Figure S18: Molecules generated by model optimized for alternating rewards from BA with TTBK1 calculated using GIN, target TPSA = 120Å 2 and target ∆G Hyd = -7 kcal/mol Figure S19: Molecules generated by model optimized for alternating rewards from BA with TTBK1 calculated using GIN, target TPSA = 70Å 2 and target ∆G Hyd = -7 kcal/mol

For legends of the outermost part of the pie-chart, see (c), as they repeat in the rest of the pie-charts. Molecules generated by model optimized for sum of rewards from BA with SARS-CoV-2 M pro calculated using AutoDock and target LogP = 2.5S5.2 Protein PreparationThe structures of the target proteins SARS-CoV-2 M pro (PDB ID: 6LU7) and TTBK1 (PDB ID: 4BTK) with resolution 2Å and 2.16Å were obtained from Research Collaboratory for Structural Bioinformatics -Protein Data Bank (RCSB -PDB). The Kolmann charges were computed, polar hydrogen atoms were added and the AutoDock atom types were defined using ADT.
